journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Non-linear thermoelectrical stability analysis of functionally graded piezoelectric material beams

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad R Eslami, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, 424 Hafez Avenue, Tehran 15875-4413, Iran. Email: eslami@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this article, non-linear stability analysis of monomorph functionally graded piezoelectric material beams is investigated based on the Ritz formulation of the finite elements method. Each thermo–electro–mechanical property of the beam is assumed to be graded across the thickness based on a power law form. Geometrically non-linear behaviour of the structures is included based on the von-Karman simplifications of the complete Green strain tensor. Timoshenko beam theory and trigonometric distribution of electrical potential assumptions are held to obtain the governing equations, describing the equilibrium state of the beam. Non-linear equilibrium equations are solved based on both Newton–Raphson and Picard iterative techniques. It is shown that response of a monomorph functionally graded piezoelectric material beam cannot be considered as a bifurcation-point behaviour. While in some types of boundary conditions, there are critical temperatures through the load–deflection path of the beam.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As one of the main categories of smart structures, piezoelectric materials have gained an interesting attention due to their coupled mechanical and electrical characteristic. This type of smart structure is widely used to control the buckling, vibration suppression, shape control and health monitoring of structures. Typical usage of piezoelectric materials involves multilayer stacking sequences. These types of structure, however, suffer from the stress concentration phenomenon near the interlayer surfaces. To avoid the stress concentration phenomenon, the concept of functionally graded materials (FGMs) is combined with piezoelectric structures to introduce a novel class of actuators, that is, functionally graded piezoelectric materials (FGPMs). Such combination has the advantages of piezoelectrics and FGMs, linked together.

Researches on the analysis of FGPM structures under thermo–electro–mechanical loadings are limited in number. Besides, among these investigations, most of them analyse the geometrically linear response of the graded actuators. In many studies, variation of material properties in a specific direction is assumed to follow a prescribed distributed function. Huang et al. (2007) developed a solution based on the two-dimensional (2D) theory of elasticity for the response of an FGPM beam with arbitrary through-the-thickness distribution of materials properties. Introducing a stress function and an electrical displacement function, equilibrium and Maxwell electrical equations are satisfied. Solution of stress function and electrical displacement function, however, are assumed to be quadratic through the span. Shi (2002), Shi and Chen (2004) and Liu and Shi (2004) performed a series of investigations on orthotropic FGPM beams. The study by Shi (2002) reported various analytical solutions for a cantilever beam where the density varies as a cubic polynomial across the thickness. Shi and Chen (2004) consider the case of quadratic and cubic variations of elastic property and density of the beam across the thickness. With consideration of linearly graded piezoelectric parameter through-the-thickness, Liu and Shi (2004) obtained the response of a FGPM beam based on the definition of stress function.

Kruusing (2006) obtained an analytical solution for a cantilever Euler–Bernoulli FGPM beam under the action of a shear force at the tip. When an FGPM beam is subjected to electrical or electro–thermal loading, Joshi et al. (2003a, 2003b) developed the bending response of the structure. It is concluded that, the behaviour of an FGPM beam is greatly affected by the composition rule of the constituents. Based on a layer-wise formulation, Lee (2003, 2005) developed a finite elements method to investigate the response of the FGPM beam subjected to the combined action of thermal and electrical loadings. Yang and Xiang (2007) performed a comprehensive study on the static, dynamic and free vibration behaviour of FGPM Timoshenko beams under the action of thermal, mechanical and electrical excitations. In this study, three mechanical equations and the Maxwell type of the electrical equation are solved simultaneously, employing the differential quadrature (DQ) method. Employing the classical, first-order and third-order shear deformation beam theories, Komeili et al. (2011) developed the finite element and finite Fourier formulations to study the bending response of a monomorph FGPM beam under various types of loading. Dynamic response of the beam employing the Galerkin-based finite elements formulation is reported by Doroushi et al. (2011) based on the third-order shear deformation theory of Reddy.

Stability analysis of hybrid FGM beams, that is, FGM beams integrated with surface-bonded piezoelectric layers is well established through the literature. Among these investigations, Kiani et al. (2011a, 2011b) studied the applied actuator voltage effects on pre-buckling force and thermal bifurcation point of the beams with general types of boundary conditions. Both classical and shear deformation theory of beams are studied. Moreover, in these works, it is concluded that, due to the stretching–bending coupling effects of the non-symmetrically mid-plane characteristics of hybrid FGMs, bifurcation type of instability occurs only in some especial cases of boundary conditions and loading combinations. Post-buckling equilibrium path of the FGM beams with integrated piezoelectric layers is also addressed by some authors. In this case, one may refer to the work of Li et al. (2009) or the recently reported work of Fu et al. (2012). In stability analysis of hybrid FGM beams, only the effect of the applied actuator voltage is considered (Fu et al., 2012; Kiani et al., 2011a, 2011b; Li et al., 2009), and the reverse effect of the piezoelectric layers is neglected since they are small enough in thickness. In FGPMs, however, this assumption is not justified and the electrical Maxwell equation is also taken into account. Furthermore, in hybrid FGMs, since the thickness of the smart layer is much smaller than the host thickness, the effect of the applied actuator voltage is negligible in most cases. This characteristic, however, needs to be investigated in case of an FGPM beam, where all the graded structures have the piezoelasticity feature.

To the best of our knowledge, unlike hybrid FGM beams, there is no work reported on the stability behaviour of FGPM beams subjected to thermal and mechanical loadings. The present study deals with non-linear thermal stability analysis of Timoshenko beams subjected to applied actuator voltage and thermal loading through the thickness. Each property of the beam is graded based on a power law form across the thickness. The Ritz-type finite elements formulation is developed to obtain the non-linear governing equilibrium equations. Two commonly used iterative schemes, that is, the Newton–Raphson and Picard methods are implemented. Response of the graded piezoelectric beam with immovable in-plane edge conditions and arbitrary type of out-of-plane edge supports to the applied thermal and electrical loads is analysed. It is shown that due to the non-symmetrically mid-plane distribution of pyroelectric effect, the problem of the stability of the FGPM beam cannot be posed as a primary–secondary equilibrium path. On the other hand, at the onset of thermal loading, beam experiences a lateral deflection. The novel contribution of the present study is that, applying the appropriate external voltage, the buckling phenomenon of the structure is controlled and postponed within a noticeable range.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: Consider a beam made of FGMs of length L, width b and thickness h. The beam is subjected to a mechanical distributed load q, temperature rise ΔT and applied voltage V0 as shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Geometry and coordinate system of an FGPM beam.
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: It is considered that the material properties vary continuously across the thickness direction according to the power law distribution. The effective material properties P can be found as
where (PU,PL) represent the material properties at the upper and lower surfaces, respectively, and (VU,VL) are the corresponding volume fractions defined as
where λ denotes the non-negative volume fraction index.
In this study, the Timoshenko beam theory is used with the following displacement field
where (U0,W0) are the displacement components of a point on the mid-plane of the beam along axial and thickness coordinates, respectively, and Ψ stands as the rotation of the cross section.

Liu et al. (2001) performed a 2D elasticity solution to obtain the distribution of electrical potential across the thickness, when the beam is subjected to a constant uniform mechanical load. Results of this study reveal that, for the case where a simply supported beam is closed circuit at both top and bottom surfaces, exact distribution of electrical potential is obtained in a parabolic form, where the peak point stands at the middle. This type of distribution, also, has been used for the other types of boundary conditions, loadings and material property distributions. Also, some authors used the trigonometric functions along the thickness direction to satisfy the closed-circuit electrical conditions at the top and bottom layers (Lee and Lin, 1998; Parashar et al., 2004; Yang and Xiang, 2007).
In this study, considering both reverse and direct effects of a piezoelectric layer, the electric potential V is assumed to obey the following distribution (Ke et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2002)
where β=π/h is the spatial function of the electric potential and Φ(X) denotes the external electric voltage applied to the beam’s electrodes.
The constitutive equation for the FGPM beam under thermo–electro–mechanical loading may be expressed as follows (Doroushi et al., 2011)

where εx, γxz, σx, τxz, Di and Ei represent the axial strain, shear strain, axial stress, shear stress, dielectric displacements and the corresponding electric field components, respectively. Here, eij, kij, α1 and p3 are the piezoelectric, dielectric, thermal expansion and pyroelectric coefficients, respectively, and Q11 and Q55 are the elastic stiffness coefficients.
The von-Karman type non-linear strain–displacement relations can be obtained using equation (3) as bellow
Since the electric field vector is the negative gradient of the total potential function, using equation (4), the electric field components are
where we have set E0=V0/h.

The equilibrium equations of an FGPM beam under thermal, mechanical and electrical loadings may be derived on the basis of the stationary potential energy. According to this principle, an equilibrium position in the structure occurs when the following condition is met
where the variation of the electric enthalpy δH is (Yang and Xiang, 2007)
where Ks is the shear correction factor and is taken as Ks=π2/12. The virtual work δR due to the out-of-plane mechanical load q is
The stress resultants of the Timoshenko beam theory using equations (5), (6) and (7) are
where NXT and MXT are thermal force and moment resultants (Zhao et al., 2007) that are defined as
Other quantities that are not specified, are given in Appendix 1.
For the sake of generality and simplicity, the following non-dimensional parameters (Yang and Xiang, 2007) are introduced and are used in the rest of this study
where DZT=∫−h2h2p3ΔTβsin(βZ)dZ, and the quantities that are not introduced are given in the Appendix 1.

Substituting equations (6) and (7) into equation (8), then integrating in the thickness direction with consideration of equations (11), and applying the fundamental lemma of calculus, the weak-formulation of the governing equations in dimensionless form are obtained as
the constants in the above equations are defined in the Appendix 2.
Using integration by parts in equations (14) to (17), the governing differential equations become
Also, the boundary conditions are
where the latter one is the electrical boundary condition, and the first three are the mechanical ones.

In the stability analysis of an FGPM beam, the boundary conditions may be assumed to be immovable, simply supported or clamped. The electrical boundary condition on each edge is chosen as the closed circuit, that is, the natural boundary condition. Mathematical expressions for each of these edges are

sec.title: Finite elements model
sec.p: The Ritz finite element method is used to solve the weak forms of the governing equations. The variables are approximated as
where Ψjα(x)(α=1,2,3,4) are Lagrange interpolation functions of degree (l−1),(m−1),(n−1) and (p−1), respectively. Using equation (21), the virtual displacements are

In this study, the quadratic interpolation functions are used to approximate the variables in the elements. Substitution of equations (21) and (22) into equations (14) to (17), yield the following finite element model
Definitions of the elements of Kij and Fi are given in Appendix 3.
The element equations (23) to (26) can be expressed in matrix form as

where [KL], [KNL1] and [KNL2] are the linear, first-order non-linear and second-order non-linear stiffness matrices, respectively, and {Fm}, {Fe} and {FT} are the mechanical, electrical and thermal force vectors, respectively. Due to the non-linear effects in stiffness matrix of the above equation, an iterative method has to be used in each load step. Two commonly used iterative schemes are the Picard iteration procedure and the Newton–Raphson method. The details of these methods are available in the study by Reddy (2004). Both direct iteration and Newton–Raphson methods are examined to solve the non-linear finite element equation (27). It is important to note that, in some cases of boundary conditions and composition rules of the constituents, the direct iterative procedure (Picard method) does not converge for a reasonable iteration steps. However, the Newton–Raphson method seems to be more rapid-convergent. This feature belongs to different algorithms that Newton–Raphson method and Picard method have possessed. In Picard method, the solution belongs to the converged solution of the previous load step. A rapid change in the graph trend leads to the large number of iteration steps. In the stability analysis of an FGPM beam, as mentioned, the behaviour is of the bifurcation type (which contains a rapid change in the graph due to a jump from primary equilibrium path to the secondary one) or the critical point (the slope of the graph changes significantly around the critical state). Therefore, Picard algorithm needs small load increments and large number of iterations when it is compared to the Newton–Raphson method. In this study, therefore, only the Newton–Raphson method is considered to conclude the results.

sec.title: Comparison studies
sec.p: The numerical or analytical results of the post-buckling analysis of the FGPM beams are not available in the literature. The FGM beams are the special kinds of FGPM actuators, in which the numerical magnitudes of the electric properties are equal to zero. Thus, to assure the accuracy of the developed finite element model, some comparison studies have been performed.

Thermal post-buckling path and end-shortening force of a thin FGM beam made of ZrO2/Ti−6Al−4V are presented in Figures 2 and 3. Properties of the constituent are Em=116.7GPa, αm=9.5×10−6K−1, Ec=151GPa, αc=10×10−6K−1 and ν=0.3 (Zhao et al., 2007). The case of λ=0 represents a beam made of ZrO2. As seen, comparisons are well justified. It is worth mentioning that, except for the especial cases of homogeneous beams, behaviour of S−S monomorph FGM beams is not of the bifurcation-type buckling. This is due to the inability of edges in supplying the additional moment to retain the beam flat at the onset of loading. Critical buckling temperature differences are distinguishable from both post-buckling equilibrium path and force-temperature path. For the case when beam is made of an isotropic homogeneous material, beam remains flat in pre-buckling state (Hetnarski and Eslami, 2009).

caption.p: A comparison on thermal post-buckling path of ZrO2/Ti−6Al−4VS−S FGM beams with various volume law indices. Results of Zhao et al. (2007) are read from graph.
FGM: functionally graded material.
A comparison on end-shortening force of ZrO2/Ti−6Al−4VS−S FGM beams with various volume law indices. Results of Zhao et al. (2007) are read from graph.
FGM: functionally graded material.

sec.p: As the second example, in Figure 4, the bending response of a C−F FGPM beam is studied and is compared with the results reported by Yang and Xiang (2007). The cantilever beam is subjected to both the electrical and mechanical loads. Yang and Xiang (2007) have used a trigonometric model, which is antisymmetric with respect to the mid-plane. Therefore, in this study, both the proposed symmetrical distribution in equation (4) and the antisymmetric model of Yang and Xiang (2007) are examined. From the results of Figure 4, it is seen that the results of this study are well justified with those reported in Yang and Xiang (2007).

caption.p: A comparison on tip deflection of a cantilever FGPM beam with λ=0.2 and L/h=25 under the actuator voltage V0=20V and distributed force q.
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: As the third example, in Table 1, the critical buckling temperature differences of C−C FGM beams are compared with the results of Kiani et al. (2011a) and the results of Fu et al.(2012), which are obtained based on the exact analytical eigen-value analysis. The beam is made of Al/Al2O3 and properties are Em=70GPa, αm=23×10−6, Ec=380GPa, αc=7.4×10−6 and ν=0.3. The case of λ=0, presents a fully ceramic beam. The little difference between our results and those obtained by Fu et al. (2012) is due to the ignorance of transverse shear deformations in the study by Fu et al., where the results are presented based on Euler beam theory. The finite element results of this study are well justified with those obtained based on an exact solution reported in Kiani et al. (2011a).

caption.p: Buckling temperature difference of C−C FGM beams subjected to uniform temperature rise loading for various values of the volume fraction index (L=0.25m,h=0.01m)

sec.title: Parametric studies
sec.p: To investigate the non-linear stability behaviour of an FGPM beam, a monomorph FGPM beam made of lead zirconate titanate-4 (PZT-4) and PZT-5H piezoelectric materials is considered. Top surface of the beam is PZT-4 rich, while the bottom one is PZT-5H rich. Thermo–electro–mechanical properties of these constituents are given in Table 2. In all the rest, thickness is assumed as h=0.001m, unless otherwise stated.

caption.p: Thermo–electro–mechanical properties of PZT-4 and PZT-5H (Doroushi et al., 2011).

sec.p: The temperature–deflection path of FGPM beams with L/h=40 is depicted in Figure 5. It is seen that, due to the non-symmetrical distribution of the material properties across the thickness, the behaviour of an FGPM beam under in-plane thermal loading is not of the bifurcation-type buckling, except for the case of the reduction of an FGPM beam to a fully homogeneous one (λ=0). On the other hand, equilibrium path of monomorph S−S FGPM beam is unique and stable. Furthermore, due to the higher coefficient of thermal expansion near the bottom surface, beam bends downward. Power law index of composition rule plays an important role in the magnitude of lateral deflection. For the constituents of this study, as power law index decreases, the structure becomes stiffer and experiences less deflection.

caption.p: Effect of the volume fraction index on the thermal post-buckling equilibrium paths of immovable S−S FGPM beams (V0=0,L/h=40).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: The end-shortening force of an FGPM beam with S−S boundary conditions is plotted in Figure 6 for three cases of power law index when beam is subjected only to temperature rise. Apparently, for the case of λ=0, when the beam is fully homogeneous, end-shortening force varies linearly up to the bifurcation point. That is because in pre-buckling state, beam does not undergo any rotation, axial displacement, lateral deflection and electrical potential. For the case of non-zero power law indices, however, end-shortening force varies non-linearly with respect to temperature in whole of the thermal loading process.

caption.p: The end-shortening force of a S−S FGPM beam for different volume fraction indices (V0=0,L/h=40).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: In Figure 7, the axial stress of an FGPM beam for the mid-span is plotted as a function of thickness coordinate for various temperature parameters. It is seen that, the top surface of the beam experiences compressive force while the bottom one is under tension. This is because of the lower coefficient of thermal expansion near the top surface. It is worth mentioning that none of the plots pass through the point (0,0). This is because of the non-symmetrical distribution of material properties across the thickness, which causes the independence of the neutral and middle surfaces.

caption.p: Through-thickness stress distribution of a S−S FGPM beam under thermal load (V0=0,L/h=25,λ=10).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: In Figure 8, the transversal electrical potential of an FGPM beam for the mid-span is plotted as a function of thickness coordinate for various temperature parameters. It is seen that, as the temperature parameter increases, the magnitude of electrical potential increases. Since there is no applied external voltage, the electrical potential is zero at the middle surface. This is consistent with the assumed distribution of the electrical potential across the thickness.

caption.p: Through-thickness distribution of electric field Ez of a S−S FGPM beam under thermal load (V0=0,L/h=25,λ=10)
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: The effect of slenderness on load–deflection path of isotropic homogeneous beams is depicted in Figure 9. Since beam is subjected to only uniform temperature rise loading, thermal load–deflection paths are of the symmetrical primary–secondary path, where the post-buckling branch is stable. As expected, the higher the L/h ratio is, the more the magnitude of the deflection is. Consequently, the bifurcation temperatures are postponed when beam gets thicker. This is due to the stiffness loss caused by increasing the L/h ratio.

caption.p: Effect of slenderness ratio on the thermal post-buckling equilibrium paths of immovable S−S FGPM beam (V0=0,λ=0).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: In Figure 10, the temperature–deflection equilibrium paths of FGPM beams are plotted for various power law indices. Similar to the case of S−S beams, when λ=0, that is the reduction of an FGPM beam to a fully homogeneous one, the problem is posed as a bifurcation-type buckling. For the case when distribution of properties is described with a non-zero volume law index, problem is not of the bifurcation-type buckling. However, the behaviour of the beam is totally different from those observed for the S−S beams in Figure 5. In the case of C−C FGPM beams, thermal moments are handled by the edge supports, while due to the pyroelectric effect, at the onset of thermal loading, beam experiences the lateral deflection. The magnitude of this deflection in initial levels of loading, however, is very small. The load–deflection path of C−C FGPM beams is unique and stable in the studied range. As seen in Figure 10, for each volume law index, there exists a unique temperature at which the deflection changes significantly with a little amount of temperature increase. These points may be called the critical points since they have high importance for design purposes.

caption.p: Effect of the volume fraction index on the thermal post-buckling equilibrium paths of immovable C−C FGPM beams (V0=0,L/h=60).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: The temperature–deflection path of C−C FGPM beams for three values of slenderness ratio is given in Figure 11, when beam is subjected to both external voltage and temperature rise loading. Due to the presence of both the external voltage effect and the pyroelectric effect in Maxwell equation (denoted by λV and λT, respectively, in equation (17)), the problem is not of the bifurcation-type buckling. However, in each load–deflection path, there exists a critical temperature at which deflection changes significantly with a small amount of increase in temperature.

caption.p: Effect of slenderness ratio on the thermal post-buckling equilibrium path of immovable C−C FGPM beam (V0=100V,λ=10).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: The end-shortening force of C−C FGPM beams as a function of temperature is depicted in Figure 12. It is seen that as the power law index increases, the critical point temperature decreases. The end-shortening force increases with temperature in pre-critical point, while in the post-critical phase it tends to be vice versa. Therefore, beam experiences the maximum amount of total in-plane compressive force in its critical point temperature.

caption.p: The end-shortening force of a C−C FGPM beam for different volume fraction indices (V0=20V,L/h=60).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: Boundary conditions effect the load–deflection path of the S−S, C−S and C−C FGPM beams and are given in Figure 13. Due to the inability of simply supported edge in supplying the extra moment, the load–deflection path of S−S and C−S is completely smooth, unique and stable. For the C−C case, however, the critical point temperature is observed in the load–deflection path. As expected, the C−C is the most stiff case and S−S is the least one.

caption.p: A comparison on boundary conditions effect on thermal load–deflection path of a FGPM beam (V0=50V,L/h=35,λ=5).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: The effect of the external actuator voltage on the load–deflection equilibrium path and bending moment of FGPM beams is revealed in Figures 14 and 15. It is seen that, applying the negative voltage to the actuator electrodes increases the critical point temperature. This feature is valid for the constituents of this study, since the induced in-plane force in the beam may be of the compressive or tensile type, depending on the signs of piezoelectric coefficients. The effect of the applied external voltage is negligible in pre-critical state, while it is more pronounced in post-critical phase. The trend of non-linear bending moment in the pre-/post-critical states is totally different, which is due to the abrupt change in curvature of the beam.

caption.p: The effect of the applied actuator voltage on the load–deflection path of a C−C FGPM beam (L/h=50,λ=10).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.
The effect of the applied actuator voltage on the non-linear bending moment of a C−C FGPM beam (L/h=50,λ=10).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.p: To investigate the effect of the external voltage on bifurcation/critical point and axial force of FGPM beams, the non-linear behaviour of the S−S isotropic homogeneous beam is examined in Figures 16 and 17. Apparently, the buckling phenomenon can be postponed by applying the external voltage. For the constituents of this study, applying positive voltage to the electrodes generates the extra compressive electrical force and buckling occurs sooner, while applying negative voltage affects vice versa. Consequently, considering the suitable applied external voltage, as the bifurcation temperature increases, post-buckling strength of the beam increases too.

caption.p: The effect of the applied actuator voltage on the pre-/post-buckling equilibrium path of a S−S FGPM beam (L/h=50,λ=0).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.
The effect of the applied actuator voltage on end-shortening force of a S−S FGPM beam (L/h=50,λ=0).
FGPM: functionally graded piezoelectric material.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: To assess the effects of direct/inverse piezoelectric effects, composition rule, slenderness ratio and the boundary conditions on the response of a monomorph FGPM beam under the in-plane thermal/electrical loads, a Ritz-based finite elements formulation is developed. The first-order shear deformation theory of Timoshenko combined with the von-Karman type of geometrical non-linearity is assumed to establish the non-linear stiffness matrix and force vector. The well-known Newton–Raphson iterative scheme is used to obtain the solution of the system of non-linear equations. It is found that the behaviour of unsymmetrical piezoelectric beams is totally different from the symmetrical one. Besides, applying the suitable external voltage may increase the stability of the beam within a reasonable percentage. The sign of the applied external voltage, however, has to be chosen according to the electrical properties of the constituents.

app.title: Appendix 3
app.p: where le is the element length.
